M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: (Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment – M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

General Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 prohibits landlords from directly or indirectly interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment by any act or omission.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14 and 18.proposition: Defendant’s subsequent actions — labeling Plaintiff a “problem tenant” and refusing lease renewal following his lawful code complaint — further evidence interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment and retaliation prohibited under G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 18.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to the greater of actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2\u20133.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2–3, because the property at issue is located in Roxbury.

G.L. c. 212.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 212 and the Massachusetts Trial Court Rules, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of this Court.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: A city inspector subsequently visited the property, confirmed multiple violations of the State Sanitary Code under 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., and cited the landlord accordingly.

105 C.M.R. 410.500 (requiring watertight.proposition: Defendant’s omission to correct the water infiltration despite notice violates applicable health and housing codes, including 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (requiring watertight walls) and 410.750 (landlord repair obligations).

410.750 (landlord repair obligations).proposition: Defendant’s omission to correct the water infiltration despite notice violates applicable health and housing codes, including 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (requiring watertight walls) and 410.750 (landlord repair obligations).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as a standard incident of a Massachusetts residential tenancy and analyzes a statutory "quiet enjoyment" claim (G.L. c. 186, § 14) that presupposes such a covenant in residential leases. While the case focuses on whether the landlord’s omissions breached that covenant, and does not explicitly say the words "every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant," its discussion assumes that such a covenant exists in these public-housing residential tenancies and describes a suit for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as the tenant’s remedy against the landlord for interference with use and enjoyment of the rented property.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
A suit for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment is the proceeding a tenant may bring against his landlord for interference with the use and enjoyment of the rented property.

... The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. Manzaro v. McCann, 401 Mass. 880, 884 (1988). Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987). Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 167 (1985). Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the defective and unsafe conditions within the apartment constitutes such interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The proposition talks about a landlord’s failure to remedy defective and unsafe conditions *within the apartment*. Blackett v. Olanoff concerns excessive noise from a nearby lounge that the landlord introduced and had the power to control, not physical defects or unsafe conditions inside the leased unit. The case stands for the principle that a landlord’s conduct (including failure to abate external disturbances they can control) can constitute constructive eviction, but it does not specifically address failure to repair internal apartment defects or safety hazards.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The uncorrected flooding and moisture rendered portions of the leased premises unsuitable for normal residential use, violating the implied warranty of habitability and impairing the Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurrence/dissent focused on the doctrinal basis and scope of an implied warranty/habitability standard, not on specific facts such as flooding or moisture in a particular unit. It discusses, in the abstract, that violations of the State Sanitary Code can render premises uninhabitable and affect rent liability, but it does not state that uncorrected flooding and moisture in this case rendered parts of the premises unsuitable for normal residential use or impaired quiet enjoyment. Using this citation to prove that specific factual proposition overstates what this opinion decides.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt:
“The tenants defend principally on the following grounds… that the Housing Inspection Department had inspected defendant’s apartment… and found said apartment to be in violation of the State Sanitary Code… and that said violations and conditions… render the apartment uninhabitable and such conditions continue today.”

“…I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards…”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The uncorrected flooding and moisture rendered portions of the leased premises unsuitable for normal residential use, violating the implied warranty of habitability and impairing the Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlord’s failure to prevent repeated flooding in the basement apartment breached both the implied warranty of habitability (because the premises were not watertight under the State Sanitary Code) and the statutory/implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court treats the recurrent water and sewage flooding as a serious interference with the tenant’s tenancy and affirms liability on both theories, making the premises unsuitable for normal residential use and impairing quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition… At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code… There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous… Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code… provides that apartments must be watertight… The jury found… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”}

Doe v. Stanton, 147 F. Supp. 2d 332, 338.raw_text: Doe v. Stanton, 147 F. Supp. 2d 332, 338 (D. Mass. 2001)
Doe v. Stanton, 147 F. Supp. 2d 332, 338.proposition: The continuing leaks and moisture problems constitute an ongoing substantial interference with the Plaintiff’s tenancy.
Doe v. Stanton, 147 F. Supp. 2d 332, 338.case_name: Green v. Fund Asset Management, L.P.
Doe v. Stanton, 147 F. Supp. 2d 332, 338.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns investment company advisory fees under the Investment Company Act and does not involve landlord–tenant law, habitability, or interference with tenancy. There is no discussion of leaks, moisture problems, or any concept analogous to substantial interference with a tenancy. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the stated landlord–tenant proposition.
Doe v. Stanton, 147 F. Supp. 2d 332, 338.relevant_excerpt: Plaintiffs commenced this action by filing their original complaint on June 21, 1996 in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. On July 18, 1997, the action was transferred to this court. In their original complaint, plaintiffs lodged against the defendants federal statutory claims under sections 8(e), 34(b), 36(a), and 36(b) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 (the “ICA”), and state common-law claims for breach of fiduciary duty and deceit.

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 477 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s dereliction of duty is a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property loss and discomfort, contrary to Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 477 (2004) (holding landlord liable for failing to correct known water intrusion).
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition frames Jablonski as a proximate-cause case for property loss and discomfort and characterizes it as “holding landlord liable for failing to correct known water intrusion.” The actual opinion concerns ventilation/moisture/odor and ant-infestation problems, a resulting bathroom fan fire, and statutory/contractual claims (implied warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, retaliatory eviction, and c. 93A). The court holds that the landlord’s long‑standing failure to correct known serious code violations constitutes breach of quiet enjoyment and related liabilities, not that dereliction of duty is a direct and proximate cause of property loss from water intrusion. Thus, the decision is being mischaracterized and does not directly support the proposition as stated.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem — a serious code violation — for over nine years. Because of the defective ventilation, the tenants were forced to keep the bathroom door shut and to run the fan continuously, a dangerous situation which led to a fire in the apartment.… On these facts… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489, 491 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s subsequent actions — labeling Plaintiff a “problem tenant” and refusing lease renewal following his lawful code complaint — further evidence interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment and retaliation prohibited under G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 18.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. O’Brien does not address claims of interference with quiet enjoyment or retaliation under G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 or 18. It concerns a public housing authority’s eviction for drug-related lease violations, the existence of good cause, notice requirements, and procedural adequacy, not landlord retaliation for a tenant’s protected complaints or labeling a tenant as a “problem tenant.” The proposition about retaliatory non‑renewal and interference with quiet enjoyment is therefore not supported by this case.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt:
O’Brien’s eviction is founded upon “good cause reasonably related to the protection of some legitimate interest of the public landlord.” Spence v. Reeder, 382 Mass. at 420.

The record before us reveals that all the procedural requirements set out in 24 C.F.R. § 866.54 through and including § 866.58 (1982) were followed. O’Brien’s remaining contentions concerning whether the panel’s decision constituted good cause have been answered in Spence v. Gormley, supra.

Alves v. Daly, 2009 Mass. App. Div. 1, 5.raw_text: Alves v. Daly, 2009 Mass. App. Div. 1, 5 (2009)
Alves v. Daly, 2009 Mass. App. Div. 1, 5.proposition: Defendant’s interference was intentional or, at minimum, reckless and in disregard of the Plaintiff’s rights.
Alves v. Daly, 2009 Mass. App. Div. 1, 5.case_name: Barron Chiropractic & Rehabilitation, P.C. v. Premier Insurance Co. of Massachusetts
Alves v. Daly, 2009 Mass. App. Div. 1, 5.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the insured’s failure to attend an independent medical examination constituted noncooperation sufficient to justify denial of PIP benefits. It does not discuss any defendant’s interference with a plaintiff’s rights, nor does it analyze intentional or reckless interference as a mental state element. The court’s reasoning focuses on notice, clarity of insurer communications, and factual disputes about cooperation, so the case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about intentional or reckless interference.
Alves v. Daly, 2009 Mass. App. Div. 1, 5.relevant_excerpt: “On the record before us, therefore, we are unable to conclude that there exist no facts in dispute whether Woods even knew of his obligation to undergo an IME, let alone whether he chose not to cooperate with the insurer. While Premier may produce evidence at trial supporting its defense of noncooperation, it was not entitled to summary judgment.”
